Name: BENZETHONIUM CHLORIDE
Description: Benzethonium chloride is a (synthetic) quaternary ammonium salt that is benzyldimethylamine in which the nitrogen is quaternised by a 2-{2-[p-(2,4,4-trimethylpentan-2-yl)phenoxy]ethoxy}ethyl group, with chloride as the counter-ion. An antiseptic and disinfectant, it is active against a broad spectrum of bacteria, fungi, moulds and viruses. It has a role as an antiseptic drug, a disinfectant, an antibacterial agent, an antiviral agent and an antifungal agent. It is a quaternary ammonium salt, a chloride salt and an aromatic ether.

environmental_biodegradations.References: Verschueren, K. Handbook of Environmental Data of Organic Chemicals. 2nd ed. New York, NY: Van Nostrand Reinhold Co., 1983., p. 244
environmental_biodegradations.Value: Biodegradation: at 18 mg/l no degradation after 28 days by nonadapted sewage.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Zeiger E et al; Environ Mutagen 9: 1-110 (1987)
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: Benzethonium chloride was evaluated to be negative when tested for mutagenicity in the Salmonella/microsome preincubation assay using the standard protocol approved by the National Toxicology Program. Benzethonium chloride was tested at doses of 0, 0.01, 0.03, 0.1, 0.3, 1.0, 3.3, 10, 33, and 100 ug/plate in four Salmonella typhimurium strains (TA98, TA100, TA1535, and TA1537) in the presence and absence of Aroclor-induced rat or hamster liver S9. Benzethonium chloride was negative in these tests and the highest ineffective dose level tested in any Salmonella tester strain was 100 ug/plate.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Toxicology & Carcinogenesis Studies of Benzethonium Chloride in F344/N Rats and B6C3F1 Mice (Dermal Studies). Technical Report Series No. 438 (1995) NTIS Publication No. PB96-162300 U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, National Toxicology Program, National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, Research Triangle Park, NC 27709
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: ... CONCLUSIONS: Under the conditions of these 2 yr dermal studies, there was no evidence of carcinogenic activity of benzethonium chloride in male or female F344/N rats receiving 0.15, 0.5, or 1.5 mg/kg. There was no evidence of carcinogenic activit,v in male or female B6C3F1 mice receiving 0.15, 0.5, or 1.5 mg/kg.
